question: True about Hodgkin's lymphoma are all except?
exp: HODGKIN'S LYMPHOMA: - HL arises in lymphoid tissue & spreads to adjacent lymph node areas in a relatively orderly fashion. -Patients commonly present with painless, non-tender, firm, rubbery, cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy and usually some degree of mediastinal involvement. HEPATOSPLENOMEGALY IS A FEATURE BUT NOT ALWAYS PRESENT - Chemotherapy & radiation therapy are both effective in treatment of HL. TREATMENT- A- Adriamycin (Doxorubicin) B - Bleomycin V - Vinblastine D - Dacarbazine
opa: Often localized to single axial group of lymph nodes
opd: Can be cured by Chemotherapy and Radiotherapy

question: A 5-year-old child presents with history of fever off- and-on for past 2 weeks and petechial spots all over the body and increasing pallor for past 1 month. Examination reveals splenomegaly of 2 cm below costal margin. The most likely diagnosis is:
exp: - Pallor (anemia), petechial spot (thrombocytopenia), fever (infection due to neutropenia) with splenomegaly suggest the diagnosis of acute leukemia. - Splenomegaly eliminates aplastic anemia - Presence of anemia and recurrent infections, go against ITP

question: About Langerhans cell histiocytosis, true are all EXCEPT
exp: DISCUSSING THE OPTIONS ONE BY ONE: a. Peak incidence less than 3 years of age - True; More common and more severe in younger children b. Radiosensitive -True - as Bone lesions & Pituitary lesions causing DI, respond well to radiotherapy c. Diffuse form is known as Letterer-siwe disease -True d. Gonadal involvement occurs - False; Gonadal involvement is usually not seen in LCH. - Involvement of bones, scalp, pituitary, lungs, hematopoiesis is seen
opa: Peak incidence less than 3 years of age
opc: Diffuse form is known as Letterer -siwe-disease

question: Most common type of ALL in children:
exp: - 85% cases of ALL are pre-B-ALL - 15% are T-ALL and 1% are derived from mature B cells

question: A child with acute myeloid leukemia presents with hyperleukocytosis. Treatment includes all of the following EXCEPT:
exp: Hyperleukocytosis: - Leukocyte count > 100, 000/uL - It is medical emergency most commonly seen with AML or CML in blast crisis - There is sludging of blasts in microcirculation - obstruction of small vessels especially in brain & lungs - Treatment: IV fluids (hydration) Alkalinization Allopurinol (to prevent tumor lysis syndrome) Hydroxyurea (for leukoreduction) - Induction chemotherapy- initiated only after leukoreduction, as it carries a high-risk of acute tumor lysis syndrome

question: In AML best prognosis is seen with
exp: - Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APML): characterized by a gene rearrangement involving retinoic acid receptor It is very responsive to all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA, tretinoin) combined with anthracyclines and cytarabine. The success of this therapy makes Bone marrow transplantation unnecessary in 1st remission. Arsenic trioxide is also an effective non-cytotoxic therapy for APML

question: A 15-year-old boy presented with 1 day history of bleeding gums, subconjunctival bleed and purpuric rash. Investigations revealed: Hb 6. 4 gm/dl; TLC-26, 500/mm3; prothrombin time-20 sec with a control of 13 sec; paial thromboplastin time-50 sec; and fibrinogen 10 mg/dl. Peripheral smear was suggestive of acute myeloblastic leukemia. Which of the following is the most likely?
exp: - This patient has complaints of bleeding along with thrombocytopenia, decreased fibrinogen & increased PT & APTT. - These features are consistent with DIC. - DIC is most commonly associated with M3 subtype of AML= APML

question: Treatment of ALL includes use of:
exp: Treatment of ALL: -Induction - 4-6 weeks. Drugs used are: Vincristine Anthracycline Prednisolone L- Asparaginase - CNS prophylaxis - Intrathecal Methotrexate +- Radiotherapy - Intensification - Methotrexate, L- Asparaginase, Cyclophosphamide - Maintenance phase - 2-2. 5 years - oral 6- MP & Methotrexate.

question: Juvenile CML is characterized by all EXCEPT:
exp: -JMML is a childhood mixed MDS/MPD that includes childhood leukemias previously classified as CMML, juvenile CML, and infantile monosomy 7 syndrome. - Remember: presence of bcr/abl fusion (Philadelphia chromosome) is not compatible with a diagnosis of juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML). Diagnostic criteria of JMML: Category -1 - Age < 13yrs - Splenomegaly - Absolute monocyte count >1000/cu mm - Blasts in peripheral blood/marrow < 20% - Absent philadelphia chromosome & BCR/ ABL fusion gene Category -2 - Somatic mutation in RAS/ PTPN11 - Clinical diagnosis of NF-1/ Monosomy-7 Categoty - 3 - Circulating myeloid precursors - Leukocytes > 10, 000/cu mm - Elevated fetal Hb, HbF - clonal cytogenetic abnormalities

question: Most common type of AML in Down's syndrome
exp: - Megakaryocytic maturation AML - Most common AML in Down's syndrome. - Blast cells in these patients are highly sensitive to medications - show better outcome than AML in those without Trisomy 21.

question: Auer rods are specific for
exp: -Auer rods are Needle-like azurophilic fusiform inclusions in cytoplasm of myeloblasts -Auer rods are most reliable morphological feature of AML -Myeloblasts Stain +ve with MPO and Sudan Black B

question: A 5-year-old boy brought to the OPD by his Father. He is having complains of loss of appetite, fatigue, malaise, intermittent low grade fever. He also complains bone pain, bruising, oral gum bleeding. On examination Lymph nodes are palpable, spleen is also palpable. Lab investigation reveals TLC of 9, 000/uL with a hemoglobin of 5 g/dL and a platelet count of 9, 000/uL. What is the next investigation for diagnosis?
exp: Above sign and symptoms and lab finding give us a probable diagnosis of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia Next best investigation to confirm the diagnosis is Bone Marrow Biopsy Clinical features:- Anorexia, fatigue, malaise, irritability, and intermittent low-grade fever Bone or joint pain, Infection Symptoms of bone marrow failure:- pallor, fatigue, exercise intolerance, bruising, oral mucosal bleeding or epistaxis Lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly. Diagnosis BM aspirate > 20% Leukemic lymphoblasta Immunophenotype: Pre B/B/T cell Treatment Induction: Vincristine, Anthracycline, Prednisolone, L-Asparaginase CNS prophylaxis: intrathecal methotrexate Intesification: methotrexate, L-Asparaginase, Cyclophosphamide Maintenance phase: 2 -2. 5 yrs: oral 6-MP and methotrexate

question: Arsenic is used in the management of:
exp: - Arsenic trioxide can be used for treatment of resistant cases of Acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML M3). MANAGEMENT OF AML: Ara C (Cytosine Arabinoside) Anthracyclines (Doxorubicin) For M3 AML: ATRA (All Trans Retinoic Acid) Arsenic

question: Which of the following malignancy is seen in male child with sho stature, low IQ, murmur in pulmonary area and lymphedema?
exp: Male child with sho stature, low IQ, murmur in pulmonary area and lymphedema suggests Noonan syndrome with pulmonary valve stenosis. Hematological abnormality seen in Noonan syndrome is Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukemia

question: Which of the following haematological malignancies can lead to following?
exp: - Image given in question is showing Gum hyperophy - common feature of M4, M5 subtype of AML OTHER ASSOCIATIONS: - DIC - M3 subtype AML - Chloromas - M2 subtype AML OTHER CLINICAL FEATURES OF AML: Pallor, fatigue, petechiae/purpura, bleeding, infection, fever, bone-pain Lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly in >60% pts

question: Commonest childhood tumor is:
exp: Common Childhood Tumors are: Leukemia (ALL) > Brain tumors > Lymphoma > Neuroblastoma > Wilm's tumor. High yield points about childhood tumors: * Most common childhood leukemia is ALL * Most common tumor in infancy is Neuroblastoma * Most common solid tumor of childhood is Brain tumor * Most common intra-abdominal & extra-cranial solid tumor in childhood is Neuroblastoma * MC primary intra ocular tumor in children is RETINOBLASTOMA * MC primary renal tumor of childhood - WILM'S TUMOR
